testimony: Yes, we would like to start the proceedings.  For the record today is Thursday the 18th November 1999.  It is the continuation of the sitting of the Amnesty Committee at the Durban Christian Centre.  The Panel is constituted as would be apparent from the record.  The first matter that we will be hearing this morning is the amnesty application of Mr M M Jili, amnesty reference number AM7643/97.  For the record I'm going to ask the parties legal representatives to go on record.  Ms Loonat, I think you're for the applicant.
Good morning Mr Chairperson, learned Members of the Committee.  I am Mrs Zerina Loonat and I'm representing the applicant, Mr Jili, this morning.
Thank you Ms Loonat.  And then for the next-of-kin, Ms Reddy?
Chairperson, I'm actually representing the victims in this family namely the Ferrero family.
Yes, it's Ms Reddy is it?  And the leader of evidence?
Chairperson I'm Zuko Mapoma, I'm the leader of evidence.  Thank you.
Thank you Mr Mapoma.  Ms Loonat, do you want your client to take the oath?

Thank you Mr Chairperson.
	Mr Jili, please tell the Members of the Committee how old you are?
I am 25 years old and I'm about to turn 26.
I was born in KwaMashu and now I'm residing in Richmond.
Which party are you a member of?
Are you a card carrying member and have you got proof of that?
And do you have proof of this?
Yes I do have that card but I don't have it in my possession right now but it is at home.
At the time when you entered politics who was your leader?
In what respect was he your leader, did he give you instructions or how was he your leader?
He was a leader in the area and we used to go and join to him as ANC members, he's the one who was giving us cards or was issuing the membership cards.
When did you join the ANC?
Tell me, was there any kind of political turmoil in your area?
Yes there was as from 1992 and from 1993.
And what did you do about it?
A certain organisation used to attack us, shoot at us and sometimes take our cattle.
What is the name of your organisation, do you know?
It is the people from Apateni not the organisation, from a Apateni and their leader was Mbashlazi.
What party did they belonged to, do you know?
How often did they attack your area?
It will be three times a week.
As from when would you say, as from 1992 onwards?
What did you do about these attacks?
That's because I didn't because I was disturbed.

Sorry about that.  I'll put the question again.
	Mr Jili, what did you do about these persistent attacks on your area?

After they had come and attacked us sometimes we would run away and go and hide in the bushes and then later we decided that we needed to arm ourselves so that we don't have to run away from our homes.
You say we decided to arm ourselves, please explain that?

I will put it this way, there was a commander.  His name is Kotele Sibonele.  He was the one who usually gave us instructions that we were supposed to go and combat them, to go in the area where we will block them from coming into our community and attack them as they were coming to attack us.
How many of you were there when you retaliated?

Sometimes we will be thirty, sometimes thirty five and sometimes less than that, sometimes twenty nine, depending on what time the attack was launched because sometimes we will wait for people to come from work to join us.
Mr Jili, when you were given instructions to fight back, what exactly was your instructions, did you have firearms, what did you actually do?
Some had firearms and some didn't have.
And do you own your own firearm?
At that time I didn't have.
Where did you get the firearms from?
When we launched attacks we usually armed ourselves with spears and sticks but Mtuduzi used to give me his firearm.
Who was he, was he a friend, a leader?  Who was he?
He was also a member of the ANC and he was one of us.
You mean one of us carrying on our fighting on a regular basis, is that what you mean?
Yes one of us who were also counter-attacking our enemies.
Do you have any training in the use of firearms?
Tell me, were these firearms supplied to you by Mr Sibonele, Kotene Sibonele, or by Mr Mtuduzi Jama?
Mtuduzi used to lend me his firearm.
Where is Mr Sibonele at the moment, your commander?
He is now late, he passed away in 1994.
On the 27th April 1993 you and some of your co-perpetrators entered the home of Mr Ferrero, the farm house of Mr Ferrero, is that correct?
Please tell us what led up to your going to that farm house on that day, why did you go and who arranged the whole thing?
Bongani Zuma was the one who organised this whole thing.

He organised that since the people from Apateni who were attacking usually go past that farm and pick up weapons there and come and attack us, therefore we were supposed to go there in that farm and pick up those firearms.
Are you saying that the victim was supplying firearms to the IFP members, is that correct?
Did you have any proof of that besides Bongani Zama telling you that?

When I was told that the weapons and the firearms were taken from that farm five of us or five guys who belonged to our community went to that farm to check if this was true and they discovered that there were weapons but then those weapons were not as many and then we believed that they were probably many other weapons in that farm because the attackers usually passed that farm when they turned to attack us.
What time of the day or night was it that you entered the farm?
It was in the morning at about 10 o'clock.
From where we camped some of us went back to our homes to go and rest because we were not asleep part of the night and ...(intervention)

Sorry Mr Jili.  Sorry, one moment.  The question I'm asking you is when you entered the farm what happened, not when you left the farm.  When you entered the farm with your five colleagues what transpired that morning.

Mr Ferrero was going towards his car and we approached him there, we had firearms and then later I heard a gun firing and myself and Sibongile and Tanda, we entered the house together with Mr Ferrero and Mduduzi came there and asked him as to where the firearms where and he only issued one firearm and then Mduduzi asked him about the other firearms and then he said he no longer had other firearms except for that one, that was the last one and then Mduduzi also asked for ammunition and later I heard a gun fire again and then I asked them as to where they were taking these - they took firearms, ammunition and his bag as well.
You say you were on the farm and whilst you were talking to Mr Ferrero you heard gunshots.  Can you please be more specific, was it on the farm or was it in the neighbouring area?
We went inside his house and Mr Ferrero said there were no longer other firearms.  We left.
Two of the occupants of the house were murdered that day, please tell us how that came about?

As we left the house we saw Mduduzi outside the veranda and Mduduzi gave me the firearm which belonged to Mr Ferrero and told me that I should shoot Mrs Ferrero.  I didn't even ask him why he wasn't the one who is shooting Mrs Ferrero, why he was asking me to do so because I realised then there that someone was lying down, Mduduzi had already shot him and then I just shot and then we left.
So you shot Mrs Ferrero on Mduduzi's instructions, is that what you're saying?

Why didn't you ask Mduduzi to shoot him himself?
Sorry, to shoot Mrs Ferrero himself?

I was afraid to ask him and it was my first time to see someone lying down dead and Mduduzi had the gun in his hand, I was scared that if I were to tell him so he may have done something to me as well.
So in actual fact you panicked, is that what you're saying?
What items were removed from the farmhouse on that day?
A belt and ammunition and pump gun and a bag.
So the purpose of your entering the farm that day was to steal the owner's firearms, is that correct?
Was there any - did you plan to murder any of the occupants before you had entered the farm?
No we didn't plan to kill anyone, I only heard a gunfire whilst I was there.
In the judgment we find that your fingerprints were found on the telephone.  Could you explain how that came about?
You mean in the court judgment?
Do you mean in the court judgment?
That's right, the proceedings at the Supreme Court.
Yes I did put my hand on the telephone and then Mtanda Tshabalala broke the telephone.  He deliberately broke the telephone.
Were you ever employed by Mr Ferrero on his farm prior to this incident?
Yes, during school holidays, winter holidays and summer holidays I will go there and work temporarily.
Was it then that you noticed this movement of Mr Ferrero handing over firearms to the IFP etc?
No at that time I was still young and I was still attending school.
So you in fact just took instructions from your senior and believed this was what was going on?
Mr Jili, the victims' families are here this morning, is there anything you would like to disclose to them that you haven't already done?

There is something that I can tell the victims' family.  It is very sad, what I did was not actually my aim.  The people who were with me at the time and who gave me instructions were older than me and at the time I was still immature and I couldn't stand up to them and I feel a great remorse that a life has been lost because of me and I would like to apologise greatly to the Ferrero family about what happened to them.  It was not my aim.

I have no further questions Mr Chairperson.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MS LOONAT
Thank you Ms Loonat.  Ms Reddy have you got any questions?

Yes Mr Chairperson, I wish to cross-examine Mr Jili.
	Mr Jili, when did you become a member of ANC?
You say that the victims were AWB people, is that correct?
Yes I'm saying so because police told me so.
Police from Port Shepstone who arrested me.

So you only learned that the victims were AWB members after your arrest.  In other words what I'm actually asking you is after you committed the offence that's in question here today then you were informed by the SAP police?
Yes before the incident I thought that they were IFP or they were IFP sympathisers or supporters.

Mr Jili, AWB members are predominantly, are only White members and I put it to you that the victims were unmistakably coloureds so in so circumstances can those victims belong to the AWB.  Can I have a response to that?
I know them as coloureds, I never knew them as AWB until the police told me.  What I knew before the incident is that they were supporting IFP.
How did you actually come to know that they were IFP supporters?

Mduduzi told us, Bongani Zuma also told us that they were helping IFP and whenever the IFP attackers were coming to attack us they used to pass through that farm and he was the one who was supplying firearms to the IFP attackers.
So are you telling us that you went solely on what Mduduzi told you?  Can I have a response please?
So in other words you actually didn't have any solid proof to the extent that these people in question, in other words the victims, were really IFP supporters?  Please answer yes or no.

Ms Reddy, just a minute.  Ms Reddy when you put the question in English then the interpreters in the box there translate it into whatever language the applicant is speaking, I'm not even sure, I think he probably speaks Zulu and there's a lapse of time between them translating to the witness, him listening to that, responding in Zulu, it goes back to the interpreters, the interpreter then interprets the question to you so you must just allow for that process to happen, alright?  So it takes a bit longer then than usual to get a response in these circumstances.
Would you please repeat your question?
You don't have any solid proof that the victims were actually IFP members?
I personally, I don't have solid proof that they were IFP members.
So you acted solely on what Mduduzi told you?
You killed two innocent people on just what Mduduzi told you?
Why didn't you actually find out whether what Mduduzi told you was the actual truth and reality before going to the place in question and actually shooting one person?

It wasn't going to be easy because sometimes if you heard something in a caucus meeting and then you take responsibility on your own and you go and check if that information is true and false then you want to know if you were checking that and they will think we're leaking the information and then sjambok you.
You make mention of a Mr George in your affidavit, can you tell me who Mr George is?
Mr Chairperson, could my learned colleague just show us where in the affidavit so that my client could refer to it?
Yes, perhaps you could refer to the page in the bundle, have you got the bundle?  I assume you've got this application bundle, Ms Reddy?
Alright, the pages are numbered, are paginated so you can just refer to the page?
Page 4?  Sorry, is it the paginated page because we've got in our bundle, the pages are paginated with a koki pen, black koki pen.  I don't know what your one looks like?
Alright, just go to the affidavit of the applicant.
It's on the first page of the affidavit.
Where does it appear, page 9?  So you don't have a paginated bundle there?
Alright, well let's try and find the affidavit.  I'm told it could be on page 9.  Is it a document, is it a fax document with some faxed information on the top there 3/11/99 16/16 etc?
It's the affidavit of Jili, the first page of the affidavit.
Alright has it got an amnesty reference number and then the heading affidavit and then it starts "I the undersigned"
"Mbekesini Jili said under oath, I'm a South African male", is it that document?
It will be paragraph 5 line 2, "George Ferrero."
Yes we've got that.  Yes, Ms Loonat I assume you've got that?
Could you please tell me who you are referring to as George Ferrero?
The owner of the farm who we attacked.
The farmer that you attacked was a Mr Edward Ferrero.
I know him as George Ferrero.  Mduduzi and them told me so.

Right, evidence would be led here by the daughter of Mr Edward Ferrero, that George actually was the grandfather on the maternal side so that is why I'm now in confusion with the said name.  You say Mduduzi or Mdudu actually gave you a firearm, is that correct?

And you also say that your political objective was to actually go to the farm in question and get firearms to protect yourselves.  So I'm having problems reconciling the two because you had firearms, you had spears, that was enough to actually enough to counteract any attacks from the IFP.  So why did you actually need to go and get more firearms for the said objective?
We went there because we needed more firearms.  The only firearms we had they were home made firearms of which there were just three.

Can I just take you back to the incident where you said some other persons from the ANC members actually went to the farm, you actually say in 1993 they went to the farm and took five firearms.  Were not those five firearms sufficient?
Only five people went there, I didn't say they'd taken five firearms, I said five of them went there.
In your affidavit five is stated?
Mr Chairperson, can I just ask my learned colleague to point to us where in the affidavit?
Yes, paragraph 6, the middle line, towards the end of that middle line.
It's in the affidavit of the applicant.

Mr Chairperson, may I address?  Our understanding, it appears that that was hearsay because he says he was not part of the delegation so it's ...(indistinct) to ask him to confirm what is actually told by somebody else?
Yes, Mr Jili, this affidavit of yours was taken I assume by the TRC.
Yes Chairperson, by the TRC investigator.

The TRC investigator took an affidavit, a statement from you which was signed on the 2nd of this month.  Now in paragraph 6 of that affidavit which is what Ms Reddy is referring to, it is said that there were some members of your group that had gone to the farm of Ferrero one day in 1993 and they broke into that house and they stole five firearms and then it says that you were not part of that delegation that went to steal the firearms.  Ms Reddy is asking you about these five firearms.  Now is this right, is this what happened, were there people who went there and they broke in and they stole five firearms from the farmhouse?  Was it something that you heard or what, where does this come from?
I heard about them going there and one of them, I saw him and he had the firearm with him, one of the five boys.
So that person, how many firearms did that person have with him, the one that you saw of the five that went to break into the house on the farm?
He only had one and then he promised that he was going to bring the rest in the camps where we were hiding.
So did he say that they took five firearms from the farm?

He counted that it was him and the others, he told me he was with Mdonda's son and Mthembu's son and Dlamini's son and he said they went in that farm and they stole the guns or the firearms and the said they were going to bring the rest in the camps.
So that firearm that he had with him did he say he got that on the farm?
What kind of firearm was it, was it a handgun or was it a big gun or what was it?

So did you see any of the firearms that this chap was talking about, this person that went to break in there whom he said that they took there, had you seen any of the other firearms apart from this shotgun?
I say another one in Reggie Mkhize's possession.

So let me ask you, how many of those firearms did you see, you saw the one with this first person that spoke to you then you saw another one, how many in total of those firearms did you see eventually?
The only guns that I've seen with my eyes were these two and then the rest I was told and I was told that they were going to bring them in the camps.
Yes and the second one that you saw, what kind of firearm was that?
Also a shotgun.  Yes Ms Reddy?

Mr Jili, I'll refer you back to your affidavit, paragraph 7 and I quote
"Myself, Mtandwa Tshabalala, Mduduzi Jama, Bongani Zuma and Zubalele Zama had decided to go and see if we can't find more firearms on the farm."
So your actual reason for going to that farm on the day in question was to get firearms, am I correct?
When we arrived there Mduduzi Jama was in front.  He started shooting and I only saw a person lying down there.
But Mduduzi also told you to kill Mrs Ferrero and you abided.  Can you respond to that please?
Mduduzi was standing right near Mrs Ferrero and then he said to me I must shoot at here and someone was already lying down, I think he was dead and then he said I must shoot and then I shot at her.
Did you question him why he wanted you to kill her even though you had the firearm in your possession?
I was panicking and scared because when I looked at Mduduzi's face he had already changed, he was scaring me and I though if I were to question him he was going to turn and shoot at me.

Sorry Ms Reddy, just to get this more clear, is it the only reason that you shot this person, is it simply because you were scared of Mduduzi otherwise you would not have shot the person he was instructing you to shoot?
Thank you, thank you Ms Reddy.
Why didn't you testify in court and come clean that you were responsible for one shooting?
I did mention in court that Mduduzi gave me a gun and instructed me to shoot Mrs Ferrero because the other one Mduduzi had already shot at.
No Mr Jili, you did not testify in court, you actually kept silent right through the proceedings?
In court I pleaded not guilty.
Why did you plead not guilty?
The reason was we were not supposed to sell other comrades.  We knew from long time that if you were arrested as a comrade you must die alone, you mustn't reveal other comrades.
So you lied on behalf of your comrades when you were under oath?
Mr Chairperson, I refer you to the application of Mr Jili.  Paragraph 10 (b).

Mr Jili, you say in your paragraph (b)
"no one was allowed to kill us except God."
Can I ask you if you are God?
No I am not God, the one reason I did this was because Mduduzi instructed me to do so and I don't think on my own I could have done something like this.
So all the time you are hiding behind the instructions of Mduduzi?
Why didn't you bring him here today to testify on your behalf?

I did write letters to all of them and I told them to come forward so that we tell the whole country the truth and I decided to apply for amnesty.  I thought since they were outside free maybe they did apply for this because people were told to apply for amnesty.
Where is your ANC membership card?
Why didn't you make any endeavours to bring that card here today so that you could offer us solid proof as to your membership?

I wanted to do so but I'm not from home, I'm from the Eastern Cape and I couldn't contact people from home when I was in Westville.  I wanted to tell them to bring it here but then I failed contacting them.
Didn't you tell this sitting that you're from the region near Richmond?
Sorry.  Are you in prison in Umtata?  You're serving your sentence in Umtata prison?
Yes I'm in prison in Umtata, I'm being transferred from Umtata prison to Westville Prison for this hearing.
Yes to come here, alright.  Ms Reddy?

No further questions Mr Chairperson.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MS REDDY

Thank you Ms Reddy.
	  Mr Mapoma any questions?

Thank you.
	Mr Jili, prior to you joining the ANC in 1991 did you belong to any political organisation?
At the time before 1990 it was UDF.
During that time was there any conflict between the UDF and IFP in your area?
So is it your evidence this conflict arose only in 1992?

In your application in page 2 of the paginated bundle, in your application there in paragraph 9(c) you are required to state the name of the victim.  You say
"There was one White man there"
and you go on to say that the White man was a farmer.  Who is this White man you are referring to in that application?
I think it was a mistake what is written there that it's a White man because it's not a White man.
So there was no White man as such, is that correct?
There was no White man but there was a Coloured.
It is another inmate from Johannesburg.
And he was interpreting to you the questions and you would tell him the answers and he would write, is it so?
How was he doing it, would he read one question and you would tell him the answer and he writes down and continues to another question, like that?
Yes he was doing like that.

So are you saying that firstly he asked you tell who the victims were and then you referred, you said there was a White man there and then he wrote down and then he continued again to ask another question and then you spoke of a White man again and he wrote down, is that what you're saying?
When I was telling him I only referred to them with their surnames.

You know Mr Jili, even before this paragraph, on paragraph 9(a)(iv) on page 2 of the paginated bundle you say there
"The nature of the offence really was to get a firearm from that White farmer."
You know, my question is to you now, are you saying this mistake was repeated on a number of questions referring to a White farmer now and again?  How do you explain this please?
I was the one who was telling him and he was writing down.  Maybe I didn't referred to him as a Coloured but I refer to him by his surname.
This person from Johannesburg who assisted you is prison advisor then inferred from the surname that this person was a White person, is that what you're saying?
Thank you Chairperson.  So before you went there you say Bongani Zuma organised the attack on that farm, do you recall that?
Not really, what I want to find out did he occupy any position in the organisation?

Sorry, Mr Mapoma.
	Who was the leader of your group when you went to attack the farm, did you have a leader amongst yourselves?
Was Bongani a leader or a commander to all of you including Mduduzi?  How would you rank the two?
I will say Mduduzi was the leader and then Bongani after Mduduzi.

The person who usually instructed us was Bongani but then Mduduzi would be leading us after we received instructions from Bongani so we will take instructions from Mduduzi and Mduduzi will take instructions from Bongani.
Thank you.  Sorry Mr Mapoma for interrupting.

Thank you Chairperson.
	I suppose there was branch of the ANC in your area, am I correct?
No there wasn't at that time in our area.
When was it launched if at all it was ever?
Siphiso Kabinde stayed at Komagoda, is it not so?  And that is not where you stayed.  Was that the place where you were, where you resided?

I don't quite understand what it means to say a branch because I thought maybe if you're asking for a branch you're asking for someone you go and report to or you ask permission for whatever, if you had a problem you will go to that person so I know that Mduduzi and Bongani used to go to Siphiso Kabinde and report to him about incidents and decisions.
And this Kabinde was residing in another area, is that correct?
Was there no leader in your area of the ANC, leader of the ANC?
He was the prominent leader in our area, there was no prominent leader like Siphiso Kabinde.
Did you ever become a member of the ANC?
When did you join the ANC?
How did you join the ANC in 1991?
In our area we agreed that we as ANC we decided to take membership cards as members of the ANC in our area.

Mr Mapoma are you moving onto something else?
	Where is your membership card now?
Where was it issued to you, who from the ANC issued that membership card to you?
Are you saying Siphiso Kabinde is the person who gave you the ANC card?

No.  When we were renewing our membership cards we took I.D. documents and we gave them and then they took all those I.D.'s to Siphiso's office and then he brought back membership cards and they were distributed to us.
Now when in your area it was agreed that you are going with the ANC were there no people who were elected to be the leaders of the ANC in that area of yours to your knowledge?
It was Bongani Zuma, Mduduzi Jama and Kotene and Sibonele.
I see.  Okay, now let us come to the place now.  Before you went you planned the attack didn't you?  You did plan the operation?

It was the thirty of us in our camps when we were sleeping overnight.  Early in the morning before we could go back to our homes Mduduzi came and appointed that some of us were going to remain and then the rest will go back home and sleep or rest and then we were to go to the farm and take the guns.
But you didn't go there to kill people but to get firearms, that's all?  Isn't that so?
And to get firearms, nothing else?  Is that not so?
And when you were inside the house Mr Ferrero gave you the firearm, he surrendered the firearm to you?
Yes.  Yes he pointed the gun to Mduduzi and Mduduzi took that gun.
Yes did you ask for other firearms?
He only pointed to that one gun and then even when Mduduzi started searching the house for firearms he couldn't get any and then he took that only one and went outside.
And that was before you say Mduduzi started searching the house and he did not find any firearms?
And that was before Mr Ferrero and Mrs Ferrero were killed?
I had already heard a fun fire outside and I think one person had already been killed outside.
Yes but that was before Mrs Ferrero was killed when Mduduzi searched the house and he could not find any firearms?
And you say after Mr Ferrero showed you the firearm Mduduzi took the firearm and you went out, is that correct?
And on your way out having got the firearm you now showed Mrs Ferrero?
As we were leaving and I was getting nearer to Mduduzi, Mduduzi gave his gun to me and he said to me I must shoot her.
You will agree with me at this stage, Mr Jili, that Mrs Ferrero was killed and when she was killed that had nothing to do now with your receiving or returning firearms?  Correct me if I'm wrong?

Yes the truth is I couldn't see the reason why she was supposed to be killed because at that time when she was killed or when Mduduzi instructed me to kill her we had already received the gun and ammunition.  I don't know why Mr Mduduzi said she must be killed.
In other words you're saying it was not necessary at all for Mrs Ferrero to be killed at that stage?
Yes it wasn't necessary at all.
But was she not killed because she happened to know Mduduzi?
Yes.  Later when we asked Mr Mduduzi why he instructed me to do so Mduduzi did say that sometimes he goes there to buy cattle and Mrs Ferrero may or might recognise him later.
Did you wear anything over your faces at all?
Didn't Mrs Ferrero know you?  You'd worked there as a casual labourer?
Yes maybe but she was old, I didn't have a problem with that.
Mr Ferrero, did he know you?
So when you went there did you expect them to know you?
It wasn't easy for them to recognise me because it had been a long time since we'd worked there.
When did you last work there?
It has been a long time.
But just an indication, how old were you when you last worked there?
So why didn't you cover your face for in case they recognised you?
I don't think he understood the question.
I was 17 or 18 years when I last worked there.
And how old were you when they were killed?
So that is not such a long time, so why did you not take precautions and cover your face so that they would not recognise you and give your name to the police?
I think it is because we took it for granted that they were elderly and it wouldn't be easy for them to recognise us.
Isn't that why you killed them?
No, that's not the reason because as we arrived Mduduzi was already in front and just started firing.  I don't know what happened but then he started firing and the person was lying down.
Sorry for that long interruption Mr Mapoma.

Thanks ma'am.
	Why was Mr Mbaba Mtola killed?
I don't know what happened.  Mduduzi was in front and I was just following from the back, I don't know what happened there.
Was he killed whilst you were still approaching the house?
So when you heard a gun fire outside when you were still inside the house Mr Mbaba was already shot, is it not so?
Mtola was killed just as we were approaching, in fact as soon as we entered the yard.  He was killed first.  I wasn't there, I was in another place so I didn't see him being killed.
Now on your way when you left the place you had two radios, is that correct?
Now when you were leaving did you take any radios from the house?
Inside the bag was there any money?
Why were these suitcase and bags and radios taken away?
I don't know where he was taking them because he was also asked why was he carrying those things and then he left them there as he was asked.
No, what are you saying now, can you explain what you are saying?
As we were leaving Bongani was asked why he was carrying those bags and then he dropped them then and there and then he started walking with us, he left those bags there.
It wasn't quite a distance it was nearer to the farm.
Who asked him why he was carrying it?
So are you saying now Mduduzi was carrying two radios, a purse and a suitcase alone when you were leaving, is that what you're saying?
Yes Mduduzi was carrying a gun, Bongani was carrying a gun and a bag, that's all.
No, no, my question is are you saying Mduduzi was carrying two radios, one suitcase, one purse all by himself when you were leaving?
Yes he had put the other items inside the suitcase.
Oh, this is the Mduduzi that threw the telephone, is that correct?
It was Mtando who threw the telephone and broke it.
I'm sorry.  Now where is Mduduzi?
I don't know where he is now.
Is he still alive do you know?

Thank you Chairperson, no further questions.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR MAPOMA
Thank you Mr Mapoma.  Has the Panel got any questions?
After you had left the farm did you get to know from your colleagues why Mr Mtola was shot?
